cwe_description: An off-by-one error occurs when a loop iterates one time too many or too few, or when a buffer is allocated or accessed with an incorrect size that is off by one unit. This can lead to buffer overflows, buffer underflows, or incorrect processing of data.
explanation: The code passes sizeof(err_str) as the length argument to sctp_sf_abort_violation. For a C string literal, sizeof() includes the null terminator, making the passed length one byte larger than the actual string content. If sctp_sf_abort_violation expects the string length (excluding the null terminator) and uses this value for buffer operations, it could lead to a 1-byte buffer overflow, writing the null terminator out of bounds.

cwe_description: An off-by-one error occurs when a loop iterates one time too many or one time too few, or when a buffer is allocated one byte too short or one byte too long. This can lead to buffer overflows, buffer underflows, or incorrect program behavior.
explanation: The code passes sizeof(err_str) instead of strlen(err_str) to sctp_sf_abort_violation. sizeof includes the null terminator, causing an off-by-one error where the length reported or used for the error string is one byte larger than the actual string content. This can lead to a one-byte buffer overflow if the receiving function allocates a buffer based on strlen but copies strlen + 1 bytes, or result in malformed network packets and potential denial of service on the receiving end due to incorrect length parsing.
